Melozone crissalis, commonly known as the California towhee, is a medium-sized sparrow native to the western regions of North America. This species is characterized by its distinctive brown plumage, with a slightly darker head and back, and a pale belly and undertail coverts.

The California towhee is a member of the genus Melozone, which is part of the larger Emberizidae family, commonly referred to as the New World sparrows. These birds are known for their ground-foraging behavior, where they use their strong, conical bills to scratch and dig in the leaf litter, searching for seeds, insects, and other small invertebrates.

One of the notable features of the California towhee is its relatively large and robust build, which is well-suited for its preferred habitat of dense, shrubby areas and woodland edges. These birds are known for their persistent and repetitive vocalizations, often described as a "cheep-cheep-cheep" or a "tow-hee" call.

The California towhee is a year-round resident in its range, which extends from southern Oregon and northern Baja California, Mexico, to the Pacific Coast of the United States. The species is generally considered a common and adaptable bird, thriving in a variety of habitats, including urban and suburban areas, as well as more natural environments.
